author: By Pam Belluck
title: First U.S. Over-the-Counter Birth Control Pill Will Be Available Soon
description: Opill will cost $19.99 per month or $49.99 for a three-month supply.
content: The first nonprescription birth control pill in the United States will be available in stores and online in the coming weeks at a price of $19.99 a month, the manufacturer, Perrigo Company, announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rod Nordland
title: Brain Cancer Was Supposed to Kill Me. Instead, It Gave Me a Second Life.
description: A devastating diagnosis prompted a reporter to revisit his past — and repair his mistakes.
content: “This disease is incurable, it’s terminal, and it will eventually kill you. Tell your children, tell your family, they need to know the truth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Clothes That Make You Feel Smart
description: Considering time, money and class at Balenciaga and Loewe.
content: Before the Balenciaga show, Demna, the mononymic creative director of the brand, went shopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.5 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs, a hillside house in wine country and a three-bedroom home with a guesthouse and recording studio in Topanga.
content: This 1957 house was designed by William Krisel, a prolific local architect, and has been owned by the same family for four decades. It was recently renovated, and additions included new appliances and cherry-wood cabinets in the kitchen and round soaking tubs in the bathrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Alabama Democrats Swarm to a Rare Chance to Increase Their Power
description: A court-mandated redistricting has made for a suddenly competitive congressional race in a ruby-red state, and Democrats have lined up to seize the opportunity.
content: When the U.S. Supreme Court rejected Alabama’s congressional map last year as an illegal dilution of Black voting power, the decision set in motion a heated redistricting battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Home Sellers Claim Warren Buffett’s Brokerage Defrauded Them
description: A division of Mr. Buffett’s conglomerate was added to a string of defendants in an antitrust lawsuit that alleges brokerages inflated commissions that home sellers were forced to pay.
content: HomeServices of America, the largest residential real estate brokerage in the United States and owned by Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Energy, is now at the center of a nationwide antitrust lawsuit with potential implications on the structure of real estate commissions nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: The Supreme Court’s decision centers on Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.
description: The provision disqualifies former government officials from holding office if they took an oath to support the Constitution but then betrayed it by engaging in an insurrection.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn a Colorado court decision barring former President Donald J. Trump from the state’s primary ballot centers on the meaning of the Constitution’s 14th Amendment, which includes a clause disqualifying people who violated their oaths of office from holding government positions in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Hiba Yazbek
title: Deaths of Gazan Children Likely to ‘Rapidly’ Rise Amid Aid Snarls, U.N. Warns
description: Delivering supplies into Gaza, especially the north, has taken on increased urgency as the United Nations has warned that many Gazans are on the edge of famine.
content: Days after an aid delivery in Gaza turned into a deadly disaster, Israel pushed ahead with another convoy bound for northern Gaza on Sunday, a Palestinian businessman involved in the initiative said, as the United Nations warned that deaths of children and infants are likely to “rapidly increase” if food and medical supplies are not delivered immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Key to Better Math Education? Explaining Money.
description: More schools and colleges are discovering the benefits of incorporating personal finance into their curriculums.
content: I offer to pay you $200 in one year if you give me $190 today. Good deal or bad deal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Biden vs. Trump: The Looming Rematch Hits a ‘Kickoff’ Moment
description: Both campaigns view this week, with Super Tuesday and the State of the Union, as a critical period that will set the tone and define the early contours of the coming general election campaign.
content: President Biden’s advisers are eager for the coming general-election fight and counting on voters to start paying more attention to Donald J. Trump, with the president himself even proposing and dashing off videos to ridicule the things his Republican rival says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: ‘Dune: Part Two’ Gives Sci-Fi-Obsessed Silicon Valley a Reason to Party
description: In a season of layoffs and cutbacks, techies seized on the second installment of the Denis Villeneuve-directed science-fiction epic by taking over movie theaters.
content: In a top-floor atrium in downtown San Francisco on Thursday evening, tech workers from Google, Slack, X and Mozilla mingled next to a pair of cardboard cutouts of Timothée Chalamet and Zendaya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: F.A.A. Audit Finds Quality-Control Lapses at Boeing and Spirit AeroSystems
description: The regulator said the audit found instances in which Boeing and one of its key suppliers did not properly adhere to quality-control requirements.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Monday that a six-week audit of Boeing and one of it key suppliers, Spirit AeroSystems, found “multiple instances” in which the companies failed to comply with quality-control requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Trump’s Tax Cut Fueled Investment but Did Not Pay for Itself, Study Finds
description: The most detailed research yet on corporate response to the 2017 Republican tax law shows modest gains for workers and high cost to the federal debt.
content: The corporate tax cuts that President Donald J. Trump signed into law in 2017 have boosted investment in the U.S. economy and delivered a modest pay bump for workers, according to the most rigorous and detailed study yet of the law’s effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Will a $1 Billion Medical School Donation Help Make the Bronx Healthier?
description: Health experts praised a monumental gift to the Bronx’s sole medical school, but wondered if it would be enough to address deep-seated problems in one of New York’s least healthy places.
content: For Trevor Barker, a first-year student at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, the $1 billion gift from a longtime former professor that will eliminate tuition at the medical school could well be life-changing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Vienna Philharmonic Tours With a Favorite Conductor
description: Franz Welser-Möst, who stands at the top of this storied orchestra’s roster of conductors, led three meaty programs at Carnegie Hall over the weekend.
content: The Vienna Philharmonic hasn’t had a chief conductor since 1933. But it has had favorite conductors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Former Twitter Executives Sue Elon Musk for $128 Million
description: The plaintiffs, including Parag Agrawal, the former chief executive, are asking for severance after they lost their jobs during Mr. Musk’s 2022 takeover of the company.
content: Four former Twitter executives sued Elon Musk on Monday, accusing the billionaire of withholding severance payments worth $128 million after he fired them from the company during his 2022 takeover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Wesley Parnell
title: Cocaine and Consequences: A Honduran President’s Trial in New York
description: The former president of Honduras is facing charges that he trafficked drugs. Hondurans and expatriates are watching intently.
content: In the clamor of the New York City news cycle, the criminal case currently playing out in Lower Manhattan against former President Juan Orlando Hernández of Honduras hardly registers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Erica L. Green
title: Harris Pushes for Pause in Fighting in Meeting With Top Israeli Official
description: In a White House meeting on Monday afternoon with Benny Gantz, a member of Israel’s war cabinet, the vice president also focused on the need for a deal to free hostages.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has emerged as one of the leading voices for Palestinians in closed-door meetings, pressed for a pause in fighting in Gaza with a member of Israel’s war cabinet, Benny Gantz, at the White House on Monday afternoon, according to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: The Top Cause of Alcohol-Related Deaths Can Go Undetected for Years
description: Deaths from alcohol-related liver disease are rising, especially among younger adults and women.
content: Alcohol-related liver disease is the leading cause of death from excessive drinking — and while it’s curable in the earliest stages, many people don’t realize they have it until it’s too late to reverse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Jordyn Holman
title: Activist Investor’s Group Raises Bid for Macy’s
description: The new offer values the department store chain at $6.6 billion. Macy’s, which just announced a strategy to turn around its business, said it would “carefully review” the proposal.
content: The activist investor group that is seeking to buy Macy’s increased the pressure on the department store chain on Sunday, raising its offer and disclosing additional details about its financing plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker
title: No Matter Race, Age or Gender, More Voters Say Trump’s Policies Helped Than Biden’s
description: Times/Siena polls highlight how comparatively well-regarded Donald J. Trump’s policies are, even by groups that were affected by policies that Democrats hope will be motivating issues in 2024.
content: Not since Theodore Roosevelt ran against William Howard Taft in 1912 have voters gotten the opportunity to weigh the records of two men who have done the job of president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Shwayder and Glenn Thrush
title: Jack Teixeira Agrees to 16-Year Plea Deal in Document Leaks Case
description: Airman Teixeira withdrew his not-guilty plea and pleaded guilty to six counts of “willful retention and transmission of national defense information,” according to court filings.
content: A Massachusetts Air National Guardsman accused of posting secret intelligence reports online agreed to plead guilty on Monday in exchange for a sentence of up to about 16 years in prison and a pledge to comprehensively brief officials on what he leaked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘Hot Sheet’ Lays Out Sweet and Savory Recipes for Sheet-Pan Devotees
description: Sip teas inspired by Frank Lloyd Wright, learn to cook the cuisine of Punjab and more food news.
content: Some cutting-edge appliances like the air fryer may have risen in popularity lately, but the simple sheet pan has become as essential as a cast-iron skillet. In the past what was often called a rimmed baking sheet and used for the cake that would become a chocolate roulade, the sheet pan, always a restaurant workhorse, is now all you need for a meal. New York Times Cooking lists nearly 1,000 sheet-pan recipes, many of them dinners. As Olga Massov and Sanaë Lemoine demonstrate in their new, cheekily titled cookbook, “Hot Sheet,” you can make just about anything but soup on a sheet pan. They take you through breakfast, lunch, dinner and dessert using mainly half-sheets (18 by 13 inches) but also quarter sheets. They discuss materials but, oddly, never mention the issue of warping, which cheaper unreinforced pans are prone to do. The all-in-one recipes like fish over cabbage; chicken with olives, dates and preserved lemon; and also sheet-pan fried rice; roasted carrots; and granola, are the best. Though you can use a sheet pan to roast a whole chicken, duck or rack of lamb, other implements could do the job as well or better, especially when a recipe requires two sheet pans, which seems to miss the point. As for a clafoutis, a pie plate works just fine. Photos of well-used pans with their smudges of dark residue might resonate with home cooks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael S. Schmidt, Rikki Novetsky, Olivia Natt, Will Reid, M.J. Davis Lin, Devon Taylor, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: An F.B.I. Informant, a Bombshell Claim, and an Impeachment Built on a Lie
description: How an unverified accusation became a lightning rod in the impeachment push against President Biden.
content: A single piece of unverified intelligence became the centerpiece of a Republican attempt to impeach President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Leu
title: A Shape-Shifting Novel About the Power of Stories
description: In Helen Oyeyemi’s “Parasol Against the Axe,” a woman’s trip to Prague becomes a meta-narrative about connection with art, people and more.
content: Helen Oyeyemi is a literary pied piper — her voice is the kind that readers gamely follow into the most bewildering and unnerving of situations. Take, for instance, the racist house bent on harming its nonwhite inhabitants in her 2009 novel, “White Is for Witching,” or the exploitative theme park where farm girls sell gingerbread and nostalgic visions of agrarian life in her 2019 book, “Gingerbread.” In this new novel, “Parasol Against the Axe,” Oyeyemi takes us to … Prague?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Supreme Court Just Erased Part of the Constitution
description: Its ruling on Trump’s eligibility for the presidency contradicts the clear language of the 14th Amendment.
content: As of Monday, March 4, 2024, Section 3 of the 14th Amendment of the Constitution is essentially a dead letter, at least as it applies to candidates for federal office. Under the U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling that reversed the Colorado Supreme Court’s decision striking Donald Trump from the state’s primary ballot, even insurrectionists who’ve violated their previous oath of office can hold federal office, unless and until Congress passes specific legislation to enforce Section 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: When a Math Museum Moves, Geometry Helps
description: The National Museum of Mathematics is shifting to temporary space in a former gym on Fifth Avenue.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out how the National Museum of Mathematics solved a problem that had nothing to do with quadratic equations or exponential functions. We’ll also look at a gathering to remember Flaco on a beautiful day in Central Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: John C. Bahnsen Jr., 89, Dies; Fierce Commander During the Vietnam War
description: One of the most honored combat veterans in U.S. history, he was awarded 19 decorations for valor. He was blunt about what his job was: killing.
content: John C. Bahnsen Jr., a retired Army brigadier general who was awarded 19 decorations for valor during the Vietnam War, mostly for his swashbuckling, hands-on command of an air cavalry troop that saw heavy combat, died on Feb. 21 at his home in Rochelle, Ga. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien, Katie Glueck and Michelle Gustafson
title: Joe Biden’s Superfans Think the Rest of America Has Lost Its Mind
description: Bewildered by tepid enthusiasm for a president they see as transformative, these Democrats occupy a lonely place in U.S. politics: “I feel like I’m the only one.”
content: Andrea Russell is a fixture on Earp Street, the quiet strip of rowhouses in South Philadelphia where she has lived for 45 years. In the afternoons, neighbors come and go from her living room as her 16-year-old cat, George, sits perched above a television that is usually tuned to cable news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Roasted Kale and Sweet Potatoes With Eggs and Rosemary Chicken Ragù
description: Leave it to Ali Slagle to bring brightness and ease to these (hopefully) last deep winter dinners.
content: Congratulations! You’ve made it through February, the shortest — and longest — month of the year. We all get extra credit too, because it’s a leap year. But next time I’d like a leap day in June, please.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: North Carolina’s Race for Governor: Expensive, Closely Watched and Probably Tight
description: The leading candidates — Josh Stein, the Democratic attorney general, and Mark Robinson, the Republican lieutenant governor — could not be more different.
content: One of the country’s most closely watched elections this year will be in North Carolina, where the race for governor will be a test of Democratic strength in a state whose narrowly divided electorate includes a crush of newcomers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: American Airlines Orders 260 Planes From Airbus, Boeing and Embraer
description: The order is the largest by the airline since 2011 and signals the company’s confidence in Boeing after a recent safety incident on a 737 Max plane.
content: American Airlines said on Monday that it had placed an order for 260 new planes in roughly equal numbers from Airbus, Boeing and Embraer. It is the airline’s largest aircraft order since 2011 and reflects the strength of demand for air travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Tony’s Booth From ‘Sopranos’ Finale Sells for $82,600
description: The New Jersey ice cream parlor where “The Sopranos” abruptly cut to black in 2007 put the booth on eBay, hoping to fetch $10,000. It sold Monday evening for $82,600.
content: Tony Soprano puts a quarter into the jukebox to play “Don’t Stop Believin’” and orders onion rings for the table. His wife and son join him as his daughter struggles to parallel park outside. A bell chimes every time a customer arrives, deepening Tony’s anxiety: Will the next person to walk through the door kill him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Ron DePasquale
title: Mark Dodson, Voice of ‘Star Wars’ and ‘Gremlins’ Characters, Dies at 64
description: He voiced Salacious B. Crumb, the monkey-lizard pet of Jabba the Hutt in “Return of the Jedi,” as well as Mogwai in both “Gremlins” films.
content: Mark Dodson, who voiced strange puppet creatures in “Star Wars,” including Salacious B. Crumb, the cackling monkey-lizard pet of Jabba the Hutt, and “Gremlins” films, died on Saturday. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: the Oscars and the State of the Union
description: ABC airs the awards show for all things film. President Biden addresses the nation across the major networks.
content: For TV viewers like me who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network shows, movies and specials broadcasting Monday through Sunday, March 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Isabel Kershner
title: U.N. Team Finds Grounds to Support Reports of Sexual Violence in Hamas Attack
description: The United Nations experts also said that they had “clear and convincing information” that hostages seized in Israel on Oct. 7 had been sexually abused in Gaza, and that they had looked into reports of abuse of Palestinians in Israeli detention.
content: A United Nations report released on Monday found signs that sexual violence was committed in multiple locations during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack on Israel and said that some hostages being held in the Gaza Strip had also been subjected to rape and sexual torture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: At Fashion Week, a Critic Considers What Clothes Have to Say
description: From Paris, Vanessa Friedman, The Times’s chief fashion critic, shared what she looks for on the runway and the forces shaping fashion right now.
content: The past month has been a whirlwind for luxury brands, models and fashion fans as designers have promoted their visions at Fashion Weeks in New York, London, Milan and now Paris. The hundreds of shows have been no less of a marathon for Vanessa Friedman, the chief fashion critic for The New York Times. (She says chocolate, comfortable shoes and her colleagues on The New York Times’s Styles desk help.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kieran Press-Reynolds
title: Playing Infinite Craft Is Like Peering Into an A.I.’s Brain
description: A large language model generates answers as gamers combine blocks of text. It can get as weird as “Farming Simulator 2013: Furry Shades of Grey” and “Osama Bin Donuts.”
content: Fuse “Water” and “Water” to get a “Lake.” Add “Fire” to “Mountain” to create “Volcano.” Combine “Titanic” and “Poison Ivy” to form something called “Poisonous Titanic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Opinions', Phoebe Lett and Alison Bruzek
title: A Nuclear Weapon Strikes. What Happens Next?
description: Here’s what just one detonation could do.
content: What would it feel like to live through a nuclear attack? A scenario that might have once felt relegated to the Cold War era now feels less and less remote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
title: Only a Trickle of Aid Reaches Northern Gaza, as Hunger Worsens
description: A small number of trucks carrying desperately needed food headed for Gaza City, but at least some were swarmed and looted by people along the way.
content: Only a trickle of aid managed on Monday to reach the desperately hungry people of the northern Gaza Strip, where the United Nations has warned that hundreds of thousands of Palestinians face a growing threat of famine after nearly five months of fighting and blockade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: A.I. Start-Up Anthropic Challenges OpenAI and Google With New Chatbot
description: Despite computer shortages, controversies and lawsuits, A.I. continues to improve at a rapid pace.
content: The high-profile A.I. start-up Anthropic released a new version of its Claude chatbot on Monday, saying it outperforms other leading chatbots on a range of standard benchmark tests, including systems from Google and OpenAI.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: How Regulations Fractured Apple’s App Store
description: As the App Store approaches its 16th anniversary, patchwork rules have turned what was a single store into different shops across many countries.
content: Since introducing the App Store in 2008, Apple has run it largely the same way across 175 countries, right down to the 30 percent commission it has collected on every app sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Key Primary Races in California and North Carolina to Follow on Super Tuesday
description: Several states are hosting consequential primary contests.
content: Typically, Super Tuesday looms large on the political calendar as the moment the presidential race moves from one-state-at-a-time contests into more than a dozen states, all at once. The delegate haul is immense, representing as much as one-third of each party’s total. The contest is expensive and sprawling and, quite often, consequential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Mary Bartlett Bunge, 92, Dies; Pioneer in Spinal Injury Treatment
description: She discovered new ways to promote regeneration in the nervous system, offering hope to countless paralyzed patients worldwide.
content: Mary Bartlett Bunge, who with her husband, Richard, studied how the body responds to spinal cord injuries and continued their work after his death in 1996, ultimately discovering a promising treatment to restore movement to millions of paralyzed patients, died on Feb. 17, at her home in Coral Gables, Fla. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Twice, a K-Pop Girl Group, Tops the Billboard Chart for the First Time
description: The act’s six-song EP “With You-th” debuts at No. 1, while Morgan Wallen celebrates a year of “One Thing at a Time” by hitting the No. 2 spot.
content: The nine-woman K-pop group Twice leads the Billboard album chart for the first time this week with its latest mini-LP, thanks to collectible CD and vinyl sales, while Morgan Wallen marks a full year of blockbuster streaming numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump can appear on ballots
description: Also, France protects abortion rights and a U.N. report on sexual assault during the Oct. 7 attack.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that states may not bar Donald Trump from running for another presidential term, rejecting a challenge to his eligibility that had threatened to upend the race by taking him off ballots around the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Desiree Rios
title: In Texas’ Largest Fire, a Race to Save Animals Big and Small
description: An elite team of veterinarians is helping to save cows, horses, donkeys, cats and dogs. “There’s been so much devastation,” one said.
content: Horses with singed tails and bellies licked by flames. Cows whose hides are spotted with burns. A baby goat, just two weeks old, orphaned by the blaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: A Potential Answer on Trump’s Eligibility, and Harris Calls For a Gaza Cease-Fire
description: Plus, “Dune: Part 2” is a box office smash.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Wanted: Writers for Awards Show Jokes. Must Be Skilled at Diplomacy.
description: Hosts who have to entertain insiders at the ceremony and outsiders watching at home. Presenters who change their minds. No wonder the bits are awkward.
content: In the middle of struggling through the opening monologue of the Golden Globes in January, the comic Jo Koy did something unusual, if not unprecedented, for the host of a major awards show: He blamed the writers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Smithsonian American Women’s History Museum Focuses on Forgotten Figures
description: An inaugural digital exhibition, “Becoming Visible,” traces the paths of five notable women whose stories have been largely erased.
content: Everyone who carried a bag lunch to school has engaged with the work of Margaret E. Knight. A 19th-century American inventor, who developed a machine to automate the production of flat-bottomed paper bags, Knight had to file a lawsuit to receive the patent for her work after a male engineer tried to steal her design. When she died in 1914, she had 27 patents to her name — but today, few have heard of her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hemmer
title: Could a New Mythology Save the United States?
description: After a career of framing the country’s past through the myths that inspire Americans to fight, kill and make money, Richard Slotkin wants to find a gentler story.
content: “A patriot is not a weapon,” Adrienne Rich wrote in a 1991 poem. “A patriot is one who wrestles for the soul of her country/as she wrestles for her own being.” The historian Richard Slotkin uses these words as an epigraph for his sweeping new work, “A Great Disorder,” his effort to redeem nationalism from its violent and exclusionary politics through an exploration of Americans’ ideas about their country. His book is the culmination of a prolific career and a new way to make sense not only of the past, but of the contemporary culture wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Supreme Court Ruled That States Cannot Bar Trump From Ballots
description: Also, Apple was fined $2 billion for thwarting competition. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: The Supreme Court ruled today that states do not have the power to disqualify a presidential candidate from running for office under the 14th Amendment, an authority Colorado, Illinois and Maine had tried to use to bar Donald Trump from their ballots. All nine justices said they agreed with the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Nikki Haley Wins the Washington, D.C., Primary, Ending Trump’s Streak
description: She received 63 percent to Donald J. Trump’s 33 percent, becoming the first woman ever to win a Republican presidential primary. But only about 2,000 people voted.
content: Nikki Haley won the Republican primary in Washington, D.C., on Sunday, logging her first victory after a string of losses to former President Donald J. Trump — who responded bitterly on social media, saying he had purposely avoided the contest “because it is the ‘Swamp.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: JetBlue and Spirit Call Off Their $3.8 Billion Merger
description: JetBlue said it would pay Spirit $69 million to terminate the deal, which federal antitrust regulators blocked.
content: JetBlue Airways and Spirit Airlines announced on Monday that they would not seek to overturn a court ruling that blocked their planned $3.8 billion merger. The decision is a big win for the Biden administration, which has sough to limit corporate consolidation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Settles Smaller Lawsuits as It Prepares for More Antitrust Fights
description: The tech giant has recently spent more than $1 billion to resolve several legal claims as more battles with the Justice Department loom.
content: In December, Google spent $700 million to resolve states’ claims that its Play Store had strong-armed app makers into high fees and tough terms. About six weeks after that, Google paid $350 million to end a lawsuit accusing it of improperly sharing users’ private information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kassie Bracken, Noah Throop and Mark Boyer
title: Economy Is Top 2024 Election Issue for This Texas Ice Cream Maker
description: As the costs of core ingredients — eggs, cream and sugar — continue to rise, Denise Eason’s economic worries deepen.
content: On Saturday mornings, 43 year-old Denise Eason sells half-pints of her homemade ice cream in front of the McAllen Library, housed in a former Walmart building. At the small weekly farmer’s market, regular customers seek out Ms. Eason’s signature flavors, all made from scratch: strawberry balsamic, honeycomb, and chocolate milkshake and fries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: As ‘Zombie Fires’ Smolder, Canada Braces for Another Season of Flames
description: A government forecast suggests that there could be even more wildfires this season than during last year’s exceptional fire period.
content: Canada’s emergency preparedness minister is warning that this year’s wildfire season will be worse than the record-breaking season of 2023, when thousands of fires burned tens of millions of acres and set off massive plumes of smoke that enveloped major U.S. cities, including New York and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Supreme Court and the Election
description: A decision by the court will delay Trump’s federal trial for election subversion. In doing so, it has almost certainly helped his campaign.
content: For six weeks in June and July 2022, a House committee held public hearings about the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol. During those hearings, millions of Americans heard new details about the efforts by Donald Trump and his supporters to overturn the 2020 election result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Do Designers Really Expect Us to Wear Those Ridiculous Clothes?
description: Our critic explains why runway shows feature outfits far more outlandish than the ones most of us actually wear.
content: This is one of those questions I have been asked pretty much every season since I started covering the runway shows. Another one is about why models never smile, which I answered last season, and I get it, I really do. From afar, many styles that appear on designer catwalks can seem more like souvenirs from a trip to an alternate dimension in the Tardis in “Doctor Who” than actual clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Chris Mortensen, ESPN’s Longtime N.F.L. Insider, Dies at 72
description: For over 30 years he covered the league for programs like “SportsCenter” and “Sunday N.F.L. Countdown.” As a sportswriter, he won a prestigious George Polk Award.
content: Chris Mortensen, an award-winning sportswriter who pioneered the role of the N.F.L. insider, reporting omnivorously for various ESPN programs on trades, the draft, free-agent signings, injuries, retirements and scandals, died on Sunday in Birmingham, Ala. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and David McCabe
title: Forced to Change: Tech Giants Bow to Global Onslaught of Rules
description: For years, Apple, Google, Meta and others operated unfettered. But new laws and regulations have finally compelled them to make major shifts to their products and businesses.
content: By Thursday, Google will have changed how it displays certain search results. Microsoft will no longer have Windows customers use its Bing internet search tool by default. And Apple will give iPhone and iPad users access to rival app stores and payment systems for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: French Lawmakers Enshrine Access to Abortion in Constitution
description: Legislators passed an amendment giving women the “guaranteed freedom” to end their pregnancies, which experts called a global first.
content: French legislators on Monday voted to explicitly enshrine access to abortion in the Constitution, making their country the first in the world to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump Prevails in Supreme Court Challenge to His Eligibility
description: The justices ruled that the 14th Amendment did not allow Colorado to bar the former president from the state’s primary ballot.
content: The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that states may not bar former President Donald J. Trump from running for another term, rejecting a challenge from Colorado to his eligibility that threatened to upend the presidential race by taking him off ballots around the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Hanff Korelitz
title: Inspired by a Real Mystery, This Novel Skewers the Art World
description: In “Anita de Monte Laughs Last,” by Xochitl Gonzalez, two Latina women working a decade apart fight to break out in the New York art scene.
content: Admirers of Xochitl Gonzalez’s debut, “Olga Dies Dreaming,” will be pleased to encounter in Gonzalez’s follow-up novel, “Anita de Monte Laughs Last,” not one but two protagonists who echo the titular Olga’s best qualities. Like Olga, they are Latina women of vision and will, who emphatically refuse to be put in a corner. But where Olga inhabited the world of wedding planning, Gonzalez’s new heroes occupy overlapping arenas of the art world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Four Years Since California Declared a Covid Emergency
description: The state recently adopted some of the most lax Covid guidance in the nation.
content: What a long four years it’s been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: This Couple Won Their Dream Apartment Through the N.Y.C. Housing Lottery
description: During the quarantine, a couple worked hard on an application for the city’s housing lottery, and their efforts paid off: a two-bedroom for $1,241 a month in Long Island City.
content: When the pandemic began, Susannah Dalton and José Ignacio Vivero were living in a basement apartment in Sunnyside, Queens. “It wasn’t bad during Covid,” Ms. Dalton said, “because it had a strong bunker feel and that was the vibe back then. This was back in the early days when we were, like, Windexing groceries.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: An Ocean Moon Thought to Be Habitable May Be Oxygen-Starved
description: A new study suggests that the amount of the element on the moon of Jupiter is on the lower end of previous estimates.
content: Under its bright, frosty shell, Jupiter’s moon Europa is thought to harbor a salty ocean, making it a world that might be one of the most habitable places in our solar system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Now It’s Germany’s Turn to Frustrate Allies Over Ukraine
description: First President Emmanuel Macron of France, then Chancellor Olaf Scholz, exposed divisions among Western countries trying to avoid direct hostilities with Russia.
content: First it was France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, who angered his NATO allies by suggesting that soon the West could be forced to send troops to Ukraine, portending a direct confrontation with Russian forces that the rest of the alliance has long rejected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Rikers Island Not Likely to Close by 2027 Deadline, N.Y.C. Official Says
description: The city is required by law to shutter the Rikers Island jail complex by August 2027 and replace it with four borough-based facilities.
content: A senior New York City official acknowledged on Monday that Rikers Island, one of the nation’s most notorious jails, would most likely not be closed by the legally mandated deadline of August 2027.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: More Screen Time Means Less Parent-Child Talk, Study Finds
description: For each additional minute spent with an electronic device, toddlers said less, heard less and had fewer back-and-forth exchanges with adults.
content: According to new research, “technoference” is real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Here’s What’s in the Bipartisan Spending Bill to Prevent a Partial Shutdown
description: Democrats rejected almost all of House Republicans’ marquee policy demands. But G.O.P. negotiators forced some spending cuts, including to the E.P.A. and the F.B.I.
content: Congress is expected later this week to take up and approve a package of six spending bills to fund half the government through the fall, after months of bitter negotiations as Republicans pressed for cuts and conservative policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: With Hope and Fear, Women Turn to Weight-Loss Drugs Before Pregnancy
description: Excess weight may increase the risk of miscarriage and pregnancy complications. But little is known about the impact of drugs like Ozempic on a fetus.
content: Anna Parker found the image online: a teal onesie with a handwritten note pinned to the front. “Someday,” it read.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Inside Britain’s Struggle to Scale Up Nuclear Power
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 4, 2024.
content: “The U.K. and the U.S. have, in a sense, forgotten how to build nuclear power stations.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Foes and Fans of Congestion Pricing Sound Off at Final Public Hearings
description: The nation’s first congestion-pricing program could go into effect in New York City as soon as this spring.
content: On Monday, hundreds of people voiced their opinions on the final day to weigh in on one of the most sweeping — and contentious — transportation projects in New York City in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: The U.N. warns that more children will die in Gaza without aid.
content: The U.N. warned that deaths of children and infants in Gaza were likely to “rapidly increase” if food and medical supplies were not sent immediately, days after an aid delivery into the enclave turned into a disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Cohen
title: Select Sources From ‘The Brink’
description: A selection of studies, research and information sources used in the reporting of At the Brink.
content: The first article in the Opinion series At the Brink walks readers through the aftermath of a single nuclear detonation. That hypothetical scenario is based on extensive scientific research and effect modeling from the Cold War to the present, as well as conversations with experts, government officials and survivors of nuclear detonations. We have compiled a selection of those sources — detailing the humanitarian, environmental and economic effects — to help make this research more easily available to readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Judge Upholds Parts of Arizona Law Requiring Voters to Prove Citizenship
description: Both sides claimed victory after a mixed decision that said voters must provide proof of citizenship in state elections, but not in some federal ones.
content: Republicans and Democrats alike claimed victory days after a federal judge issued a mixed decision in Arizona’s ongoing battles over voting rights and public trust in elections, upholding requirements for voters to prove their citizenship but limiting the ways that voters could be disqualified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Lawyers Offer New Witness in Effort to Disqualify Trump Prosecutors in Georgia
description: The potential witness, an assistant district attorney outside Atlanta, suggested in a statement that the judge had heard misleading testimony about the prosecutors’ romance.
content: Defense lawyers in the Georgia election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump say they want to put someone on the stand whose testimony could back up  their assertion that Terrence Bradley, a witness in their effort to disqualify the prosecutors running the case, gave misleading testimony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: RuPaul Is Sending a Rainbow Bus to Give Away Books Targeted by Bans
description: The star, whose show “RuPaul’s Drag Race” has an international following, is one of the founders of a new online bookstore promoting underrepresented authors. The giveaways are part of its outreach.
content: At a time of book bans and efforts by state legislatures to ban drag shows, the performer and television producer who is arguably the country’s most famous drag star, RuPaul, is the co-founder of a new online bookstore that will be sending a rainbow school bus from the West Coast to the South to distribute the very books targeted by those bans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Scott
title: Charmed by a City Off Thailand’s Beaten Path
description: Centuries-old wooden temples, a graceful river and an unexpected chicken fixation make Lampang, in Northern Thailand, a delightful destination away from the crowds.
content: Thailand is renowned among hard-charging tourists for nightlife in Bangkok, full moon parties on Koh Phangan island and hedonistic walking streets in Pattaya. It’s also a magnet for the bohemian and wellness crowds who flock to the mountain destinations of Chiang Mai and Pai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Chiarito, Farrah Anderson, Dave Philipps and Mitch Smith
title: Supreme Court Ruling Settles Ballot Questions, but Hardens Political Divisions
description: Reaction to the ruling showed that the challenges to Donald Trump’s candidacy had reinforced partisan lines and angered Republicans who saw the lawsuits as antidemocratic.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court brought certainty on Monday to a primary season muddled by confusing and divergent state-level rulings by deciding unanimously that the 14th Amendment did not allow states to disqualify former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Bringing ‘Teeth,’ a Feminist Awakening With a Lethal Bite, to the Stage
description: Michael R. Jackson is helping adapt the darkly comic horror film into a musical. But can a show about a teenager with vagina dentata sing?
content: Michael R. Jackson doesn’t have a vagina. He also doesn’t not have one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Why It’s So Challenging to Land Upright on the Moon
description: Two spacecraft have ended up askew on the lunar surface this year. It is easier to tip over in the weaker gravity on the moon than you may imagine.
content: When the robotic lander Odysseus last month became the first American-built spacecraft to touch down on the moon in more than 50 years, it toppled over at an angle. That limited the amount of science it could do at the lunar surface, because its antennas and solar panels were not pointed in the correct directions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The ZIP Code Shift: Why Many Americans No Longer Live Where They Work
description: A new study shows that white-collar employees who can work remotely now live roughly twice as far from their offices as they did prepandemic.
content: In 2020, Virginia Martin lived two and a half miles from her office. Today, the distance between her work and home is 156.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What’s Your Favorite Kind of TikTok Video?
description: Elaborate, logic-defying trick-shot videos have found an avid following on social media. Are you a fan?
content: Do you like watching or creating videos on TikTok? (Or, if you’re not on TikTok, then on YouTube or other video platforms?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: American Sign Language Reveals Wordplay Beyond Sound
description: In a visual language, a subtle hand movement can help you get the joke.
content: Nobody talks, if they can help it, at the Sign Language Center in New York City. The practice is both instructive and courteous, since three classes in American Sign Language — packed to the gills each semester with mostly hearing students — are held simultaneously in a single room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: Why Is There No Oscar for Best Choreography?
description: Imaginative dance abounds in Hollywood, but its creators remain unheralded at awards time.
content: If you’ve watched this year’s Oscar-nominated films — actually, if you’ve been in a movie theater at all recently — you’ve almost certainly seen the work of a choreographer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum, Jesse McKinley and Kate Christobek
title: Key Figure in Trump’s Business Pleads Guilty to Felony Perjury
description: Allen H. Weisselberg, the former Trump Organization finance chief, has already spent time at the Rikers Island jail complex. The perjury plea will send him back.
content: Allen H. Weisselberg, former President Donald J. Trump’s longtime financial gatekeeper, pleaded guilty to felony perjury charges in a Manhattan courtroom on Monday, the latest twist in a tortured legal odyssey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Newly Released Messages Detail Roots of the ‘Fake Electors’ Scheme
description: Emails and texts unearthed in a lawsuit show how key figures intended their plan to create a “cloud of confusion” to help keep Donald Trump in office after his 2020 election loss.
content: Just five days after Election Day in 2020, a conservative lawyer named Kenneth Chesebro emailed a former judge who was working for the Trump campaign in Wisconsin, James R. Troupis, pitching an idea for how to overturn the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Natan Odenheimer
title: Gaza War Is Shifting Ties Between Secular and Ultra-Orthodox Israelis
description: Israel’s Haredi minority has long lived apart from the nation’s mainstream, but fighting has both widened that divide and in some ways helped to bridge it.
content: In a neighborhood of Jerusalem, ultra-Orthodox Jewish residents cheered a soldier returning from military service. At a religious seminary, similarly devout students gathered to hear an officer talk about his military duties. And at a synagogue attended by some of the most observant Jews in the country, members devoted a Torah scroll in memory of a soldier slain in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Is the Leading Man
description: And Mitch McConnell is leaving the scene.
content: Gail Collins: So, Bret — are you gonna miss Mitch McConnell?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Library Fees? No Problem. Just Show Us Your Cat Photos.
description: A program this month encourages library patrons in Worcester, Mass., who have lost or damaged books or other items to reactivate their accounts. All they need is a picture of a cat.
content: Finally, there is something cats can do for humans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 4, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 4, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea Moves to Suspend Licenses of Thousands of Protesting Doctors
description: The drastic step came after weeks of protests from interns and residents opposed to a government plan to increase medical school admissions.
content: The South Korean government on Monday said that it was moving to suspend the licenses of thousands of doctors who walked off the job nearly two weeks ago, threatening to escalate a dispute that has shaken the nation’s health care system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: An Antibiotic After Sex Greatly Reduced Syphilis and Chlamydia Cases
description: New cases fell by half in just over a year, San Francisco health officials reported.
content: A single dose of doxycycline, a widely used antibiotic, taken after sex halved the incidence of chlamydia and early syphilis among gay and bisexual men and transgender women in San Francisco, city health officials announced on Monday. The findings offered a glimmer of hope amid a rising tide of sexually transmitted infections nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Thieves Stole a Formula 1 Driver’s Ferrari. It Turned Up 28 Years Later.
description: Gerhard Berger unsuccessfully tried to chase down the thief in a Volkswagen Golf back in 1995. Now, the car has been tracked down.
content: As a driver on the glamorous, jet-setting Formula One circuit, naturally the Austrian Gerhard Berger drove some serious iron, even away from the track: a red Ferrari 512M Testarossa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle and Adam Satariano
title: Apple Fined $2 Billion by E.U. for Using App Store to Thwart Competition
description: Apple said it would appeal the penalty, the latest in a series of regulatory setbacks for the tech giant.
content: Apple on Monday was fined 1.8 billion euros ($1.95 billion) by European Union regulators for thwarting competition among music streaming rivals, a severe punishment levied against the tech giant in a long-simmering battle over the powerful role it plays as gatekeeper of the App Store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Putting a New Twist on a Classic Puzzle
description: The New York Times Games team discusses its creative process.
content: Attention all Connections fiends, Wordle lovers and Spelling Bee solvers: Strands is a new game that the New York Times Games team is beta-testing. It will be free for everyone to play on the web beginning March 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Braude
title: Italy’s Oscar Nominee Is a Great Film, but It Doesn’t Tell the Whole Story
description: “Io Capitano” ends where many would have wanted it to continue.
content: Of all the offerings this Oscar season, one stands out: “Io Capitano.” A nominee for best international feature film, it is a visually stunning and often harrowing account of the journey from West Africa to Europe. Based on many real-life stories, it shows the horrors of the perilous route across the Sahara and the Mediterranean Sea that more than one million people have taken over the past decade, along which thousands have died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 7 Expert Tips for Cooking Chicken
description: In the third installment of her YouTube series, the cookbook author and chef Sohla El-Waylly will teach you how to master the basics of the bird.
content: For beginners and experienced cooks alike, preparing chicken can come with a lot of questions (and nerves!). Am I going to get salmonella? How do I butcher a whole bird? Am I doomed to an eternity of dry breast meat? In the third installment of her YouTube series, Cooking 101, the chef and cookbook author Sohla El-Waylly will help you master the basics of the bird, then set you up with a handful of recipes that highlight white and dark meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Haley Is Still Struggling to Deal With Trump’s Grip on Their Party
description: Nikki Haley has become the voice of Republicans looking for an alternative to Donald Trump. But she has been a reluctant messenger.
content: Nikki Haley lately has been making the case that former President Donald J. Trump has transformed the Republican Party into his personal “playpen.” In media appearances and at rallies as she crisscrosses the country leading up to Super Tuesday this week, she has argued that Mr. Trump has installed loyalists in key party positions and pushed for changes in primary rules to serve himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Lynn Levy, Sonia Herrero and Alissa Wilkinson
title: A Best Picture Underdog You Should Know
description: Our critic on ‘The Zone of Interest’
content: This year, the list of nominees for the Academy Award for best picture includes some of the most talked about movies of the year, like “Oppenheimer,” “Barbie,” and “Killers of the Flower Moon.” But you may find that a few films on that list aren’t as familiar. Our critic Alissa Wilkinson is here to introduce you to some of those lesser-known movies, and tell you why they may be worth your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Atul Loke and Mujib Mashal
title: Big-League Dreams
description: Maybe, just maybe, that was their future on the screen. How a new cricket league inspired two sisters in a Punjab village.
content: We met the two sisters in a small village a thousand miles away from where the main event was taking place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Juli Lynne Charlot, Creator of the Poodle Skirt, Dies at 101
description: Ms. Charlot’s creation merged seamlessly with the carefree youth culture of the 1950s, becoming visual shorthand for the entire decade.
content: What’s a nice Jewish viscountess to do when she has a title but no money, a party invitation but no clothes and a pair of scissors but no sewing skills?
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Poll Reflecting Worries About Biden’s Age
description: Readers react to a front-page story about a new Times/Siena College poll. Also: Fight on, Nikki Haley; airdrops to Gaza; death in Gaza.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Deese, Jonathan Gruber and Ryan Cummings
title: The Miracle Weight-Loss Drug Is Also a Major Budgetary Threat
description: Ozempic threatens to bust the national budget. That may finally force the government to address the problem of overly expensive medical treatments.
content: The U.S. health care system has struggled for decades with the tension between providing incentives for pharmaceutical innovation and keeping breakthroughs affordable for those who would most benefit from them. Even as countries around the world have stepped in to require lower-priced drugs for their citizens, the United States has been reticent to do so. As a result, U.S. consumers pay the highest prices in the world for drugs, by a wide margin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: San Francisco Art Institute Headquarters Sold to Group Led by Laurene Powell Jobs
description: The sale includes a 1931 Diego Rivera mural, which has been valued at $50 million.
content: The main campus of the bankrupt San Francisco Art Institute, which is home to a beloved Diego Rivera mural, has been sold to a new nonprofit organization led by the philanthropist Laurene Powell Jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Schiff Led the ‘Nerd Caucus’ Before the Trump Era. Now He’s a Senate Favorite.
description: Representative Adam Schiff has controlled the Senate race in California with robust fund-raising and is trying to elbow out his biggest Democratic threat by helping a perfect Republican foil.
content: Before Representative Adam B. Schiff became famous as the chief congressional tormentor of former President Donald J. Trump, his professional hallmark was his low profile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Chris Buckley
title: China Scraps Premier’s Annual News Conference in Surprise Move
description: The decision is a break from a decades-long tradition by the country’s No. 2 official and comes as Xi Jinping, the top leader, consolidates his power.
content: China’s premier will no longer hold a news conference after the country’s annual legislative meeting, Beijing announced on Monday, ending a three-decades-long practice that had been an exceedingly rare opportunity for journalists to interact with top Chinese leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Apparently Healthy, but Diagnosed With Alzheimer’s?
description: New criteria could lead to a dementia diagnosis on the basis of a simple blood test, even in the absence of obvious symptoms.
content: Determining whether someone has Alzheimer’s disease usually requires an extended diagnostic process. A doctor takes a patient’s medical history, discusses symptoms, administers verbal and visual cognitive tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Flaco Never Had a Chance
description: As human populations grow and the built environment expands, protecting the creatures who share our ecosystems will become more difficult and crucial.
content: It’s been more than a week since I read the news and I can still hardly believe it. Flaco, the Eurasian eagle-owl who escaped the Central Park Zoo and spent a year on the lam in Manhattan, is dead. My disbelief is of a piece with the grief I feel at news of an unexpected human death. How can a vibrant, irreplaceable creature be safely here among us one instant and irretrievably gone the next? How is that even possible?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Will Shortz, New York Times Crossword Editor, Says He Is Recovering From a Stroke
description: Mr. Shortz, who has been with The Times for three decades and also hosts NPR’s “Sunday Puzzle,” said on Sunday that he had a stroke in February but was recovering.
content: Will Shortz, crossword editor of The New York Times and the host of NPR’s “Sunday Puzzle,” is recovering from a stroke, he said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: In Rare Interview, Biden Insists He Is Democrats’ Best Option Against Trump
description: The president told The New Yorker, “If you thought you were best positioned to beat someone who, if they won, would change the nature of America, what would you do?”
content: In a wide-ranging Oval Office interview with The New Yorker, President Biden expressed confidence that he would win re-election in 2024, laid out his rationale for running for a second term despite questions over his age and said that he doubted former President Donald J. Trump would accept the results of the November contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Highlights of the Supreme Court’s Opinions on Trump’s Ballot Eligibility
description: The main opinion was a joint ruling that was not signed by any particular justice. None of the opinions addressed whether Donald J. Trump engaged in insurrection.
content: The Supreme Court on Monday overturned a Colorado court ruling that had disqualified former President Donald J. Trump from the state’s primary ballot, concluding that the Constitution does not allow states to invoke the 14th Amendment to bar presidential candidates from seeking office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: chronology
description: This word has appeared in 65 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word chronology has appeared in 65 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 24 in “‘Gran Turismo’ Review: Once Upon a Pair of Sticks” by Nicolas Rapold:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: LeBron James and Drake Make a Big Bet on the PGA Tour
description: The basketball star and rapper are investing in the professional golf competition, marking their latest push into sports.
content: Just over a month ago, a group of financiers and sports team owners, led by Fenway Sports Group, said it would invest up to $3 billion in the PGA Tour, a watershed deal that gave players equity in the league as it fends off competition from the Saudi-backed LIV Golf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn and Kaiti Sullivan
title: Paid Family Caregivers in Indiana Face Steep Cutbacks
description: Now that federal pandemic-era funds are shrinking, states like Indiana are ending or curtailing programs that finance home care by relatives of seriously ill children and adults.
content: Kacey Poynter doesn’t have to commute far to clock in for work. She’s a paid caregiver and simply rolls out of bed to tend to her charge: her 2-year-old son, who sleeps in a portable playpen right beside her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scaachi Koul
title: The Pitbull Impersonator and Killer Whale Who Both Miss Their Moms
description: In her novel “Say Hello to My Little Friend,” Jennine Capó Crucet explores existential questions of isolation and belonging through two unlikely figures.
content: OK, stop me if you’ve heard this one before: A young Pitbull impersonator in Miami named Ismael grows obsessed with a killer whale held in captivity named Lolita while he attempts to both remake himself in the image of “Tony Montana for the new millennium” and untangle the mystery of his mother’s death more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Harris Calls for an ‘Immediate Cease-Fire’ in Gaza
description: The vice president urged Hamas to agree to a six-week cease-fire proposal and called on Israel to increase the flow of aid into the enclave.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris on Sunday called for an “immediate cease-fire” in Gaza, saying that Hamas should agree to the six-week pause currently on the table and that Israel should increase the flow of aid into the besieged enclave amid a humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: London Bids Farewell, for Now, to a Beloved, Overstuffed Walrus
description: A taxidermy gallery known for its bulky centerpiece is closing for a two-year renovation.
content: Southeast London has temporarily lost one of its most famous residents: a giant taxidermy walrus that has been on display for more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Hisako Ueno
title: Racial Profiling in Japan Is Prevalent but Unseen, Some Residents Say
description: Experts say the country’s first lawsuit about police discrimination against foreign-born residents highlights a systematic problem.
content: It’s not that there is anything bad about your hair, the police officer politely explained to the young Black man as commuters streamed past in Tokyo Station. It’s just that, based on his experience, people with dreadlocks were more likely to possess drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malika Khurana and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Tracking an Invisible Climate Menace From 360 Miles Above
description: A new satellite will detect emissions of methane, an invisible yet potent gas that is dangerously heating the planet.
content: A new satellite will detect emissions of methane, an invisible yet potent gas that is dangerously heating the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer

title: Read the Decision in the Trump Colorado Ballot Case
